title: New vs Old Digital Cameras
body: <p>We got a <a href="http://www.usa.canon.com/consumer/controller?act=ModelTechSpecsAct&amp;fcategoryid=145&amp;modelid=12956" title="Canon PowerShot SD630">new camera</a> a few months ago to replace my wife's stolen Casio Exilim EX-Z750. The Casio was nice, but it wasn't as reliable as our <a href="http://www.usa.canon.com/consumer/controller?act=ModelTechSpecsAct&amp;fcategoryid=145&amp;modelid=8288" title="Canon PowerShot A40">good old A40</a>. It's amazing how much better the <a href="http://www.dpreview.com/reviews/compare_post.asp?method=sidebyside&amp;cameras=canon_a40%2Ccanon_sd630&amp;show=all" title="Canon PowerShot A40 vs. Canon PowerShot SD630">new SD630 is compared to the old A40</a>. The only feature that the new one doesn't have that the old one does (that I'll actually miss) is that you can't manually set the shutter speed. It isn't often I actually use this feature, but for shots of the <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diesel_travis/235421729/">xmas</a> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diesel_travis/235421731/in/photostream/">tree</a>, or any <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diesel_travis/39412630/">other</a> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diesel_travis/39065066/">night</a> <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diesel_travis/170251226/">shot</a>, nothing compares to a long exposure shot. Or maybe I just need to read the manual again and figure out how to take night shots.</p>
